content: @WG-prioritization we will be starting our meeting in ~ 24 mins
@WG-prioritization :wave: everyone, please add a :wave: so we can all know who is participating in the meeting
as a way to start this meeting I guess we can comment quickly some things that have happened since last meeting
first of all I've re-worked a bit our set of documents, the idea would be to try to get rid of most of them
an important one for this moment is the Check-ins document
which has the things that have happened, but it's possible that something is lacking

Current

  • We have a repo for the working group https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/ and we are mainly handling our todo list as issues there.
  • Our procedure automation cli is complete now but we still need to integrate with the Zulip bot.
  • We have added Pre-FCP and FCP information to the announcements.
all that are things that happened since our last meeting so :+1:
but there's more I think
if I remember correctly @o0Ignition0o - Jeremy Lempereur opened a PR with the priority levels
@apiraino opened 2 PRs, one to document triagebot and another to document our procedure, which would replace this document
also we've moved all of our issues to github
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues
do someone else have some other status update that I may have missed?

About automation, I've been working on implementing a system for handling commands in Zulip with triagebot. It's almost done, but it's clearly not as clean as the rest of triagebot's codebase :grinning:

Santiago Pastorino said:

apiraino opened 2 PRs, one to document triagebot and another to document our procedure, which would replace this document

note: since one is quite a "big" task, instead of iterating too much on github, we have moved the document on hackmd, then I will rebase on github when it is in better shape
ok
something I want to add to the agenda, if possible: The weekly review of perf improvements/regressions
(right now its being driven pretty much solely by nick nethercote, but i think it would be good distributing that work, or at least get some other people trained in how to do it.)
I think it could fit well in our async process for preparing the agenda?
yes I believe that is very true
uf
if anything, I suspect figuring out how best to drive that work asynchronously would be the main task
and it is a task that this group has become experts in
(i probably should have cc'ed @njn with the comment above)
that's a good idea :)
I guess the main question is how do we organize to do so?
I guess I'd start coordinating with @njn and mainly asking how can we help them?
so we could either try to figure out how best to do it as a group, or one or two people could volunteer to deep dive into the question of what best to do here
yeah, engaging directly with @njn seems like a good idea
One question I personally have is: what is expected from this "weekly review of compiler performance"?
in this #t-compiler/wg-prioritization > tweak perf report to include issue numbers explicitly topic I was also pinging njn about tweaking the report
I guess we can keep discussing with them about all this and to see how to better help there
@LeSeulArtichaut my impression is that the two main goals are: 1. celebrate successes and 2. identify "significant" regressions so that we can decide whether to invest effort in fixing them
i think doing the checks more frequently could benefit as it would be easier to spot regressions and esp what's cuasing them
So we'd need to have performance "stats", analyze them, and do the work of identifying the culprits of perf regressions. Is that vaguely correct?
anyway, back to the issues ... https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues

LeSeulArtichaut said:

So we'd need to have performance "stats", analyze them, and do the work of identifying the culprits of perf regressions. Is that vaguely correct?

yeah I think so, not only about regressions but also about perf wins
what I think is hard is to split this task to be honest
I'd just end looking at the entire week commits and see what has happened, so basically doing the same work njn is doing

Santiago Pastorino said:

what I think is hard is to split this task to be honest

We can at least do a rotation, e.g. that person does the perf report for that week
anyway, it may be good because we can come up with things that njn may have missed

Santiago Pastorino said:

I'd just end looking at the entire week commits and see what has happened, so basically doing the same work njn is doing

yeah, its not 100% clear whether you can break up the work and paralllelize it

LeSeulArtichaut said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

what I think is hard is to split this task to be honest

We can at least do a rotation, e.g. that person does the perf report for that week

right, anyway, let's see what njn thinks about this because my impression is that njn is interested in doing this work regardless of what we do :)
so back to the issues ... https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues

yeah okay lets talk to @njn . My personal guess is that even if @njn wants to continue being the primary driver, it still makes sense to share the knowledge of the process, if only to decrease the "bus factor"
but yes, back to issues!

pnkfelix said:

yeah okay lets talk to njn . My personal guess is that even if njn wants to continue being the primary driver, it still makes sense to share the knowledge of the process, if only to decrease the "bus factor"

agreed
In all the issues I think all of them are either blocked or in progress
so about the issues, @LeSeulArtichaut, you were saying that you were working on this one https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues/1, right?
except maybe compiler-team-prioritization#5

Santiago Pastorino said:

so about the issues, LeSeulArtichaut, you were saying that you were working on this one https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues/8, right?

I'm working on a way to handle Zulip commands more efficiently, which this will need
ohh I see
It pretty much blocks #1 and #8

LeSeulArtichaut said:

In all the issues I think all of them are either blocked or in progress

when you say blocked, what and why do you think things are blocked?

LeSeulArtichaut said:

It pretty much blocks #1 and #8

I guess I see a bit of what you meant :)
Yes, I meant blocked for the triagebot stuff
right
ok, I guess all that can be assigned now, it's already assigned
do someone want to comment something else? because I don't have any other thing to share or discuss
other than ... now that we are a bit more organized, this meeting taking 1h seems to much, maybe we can shorten it to 30 mins
IMO the only issue that we may want to discuss in a meeting is #5? But that can wait a later meeting
we had a discussion last time about moving from "critical, high, low" things to somthing that's more date-based
yeah this is a good topic to discuss

DPC said:

we had a discussion last time about moving from "critical, high, low" things to somthing that's more date-based

That's exactly #5 I think
right
just want to add that we have milestones already that we could possibly use
To track things like the proposed defer-until-release issues?
do people want to discuss this now? we have 25 more minutes or we could defer this a bit more :)
I'm ok with whatever to be honest

Santiago Pastorino said:

do people want to discuss this now? we have 25 more minutes or we could defer this a bit more :slight_smile:

Either is fine to me
currently we use milestones on issues to denote which issues are probably going to get merged into nightly (the milestones are numbered as per the release with a due date of the release date)
if we are all neutral I have no idea what to do :joy:, because I'm also neutral
I don't think any team use them that often though, so maybe we could use it :grinning:
@DPC do you want to discuss this now?

Santiago Pastorino said:

if we are all neutral I have no idea what to do :joy:, because I'm also neutral

This meeting was supposed to last 1h so I think we could do it now? And have shorter meetings from now on?
you're the one that can tie break :)
i'm neutral as well :grinning:
Let's do it now
pheww thanks :P
DECISION MAN
the hero we need
hehe
4 mins late, but we'll consider :stuck_out_tongue:
so what are our options?
@pnkfelix you had some strong thoughts about this
maybe before discussing options, we discuss the major issue with our current setup?
I'm kind of also neutral to this to be honest, right now I'm not sure why do we need to migrate to some time based schema
There was a document from pnkfelix or nikomatsakis (can't remember) about this, right?
yeah there were some documents
given that the process has changed, I guess it's better to defer it for a while so that we can judge better based on new prioritisation strategy.

DPC said:

given that the process has changed, I guess it's better to defer it for a while so that we can judge better based on new prioritisation strategy.

I think we can propose some ideas then?
but I believe that if we give a precise definition to the P-* labels it's not certain why would we need hz kind of labels
well other than a defer until next release kind of label
Also this question seems kind of tied to the "how to handle P-high issues" question
right
I think it is about how we handle every already prioritized issue :)
in my opinion we lack a defer until next release kind of idea
the rest are kind of covered

Santiago Pastorino said:

in my opinion we lack a defer until next release kind of idea

What kind of issues would you put in this defer-until-release state?
or well maybe are not but will when we define how do we want to handle every different priority level

LeSeulArtichaut said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

in my opinion we lack a defer until next release kind of idea

What kind of issues would you put in this defer-until-release state?

we had a P-critical issue that the fix was a bit risky and broke some crates
we decided to merge as soon as the next release has happened so we had the maximum amount of testing time
So this often applies to PRs?
do we want to tag issues with this?

Santiago Pastorino said:

well other than a defer until next release kind of label

we can use the milestones for that
I'm pretty sure we'll never have to handle P-medium and P-low issues, right? So in the end what we're left with in the end is how do we handle P-high and P-critical issues.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71896
was that one
my bigger concern is how do we downgrade/upgrade priority over time

DPC said:

my bigger concern is how do we downgrade/upgrade priority over time

I think when there is a major event in an issue we can tag I-prioritize and have an async discussion as usual?

LeSeulArtichaut said:

I'm pretty sure we'll never have to handle P-medium and P-low issues, right? So in the end what we're left with in the end is how do we handle P-high and P-critical issues.

right, and we kind of try as much as we can to close P-critical on every release and do our best effort about P-high
to be honest about P-high I have no idea what else we could do
other than best effort
i mean at some stage we will have to visit all p-medium issues, and see if some of them could be made p-high
ohh I see what you meant
let me re-phrase that differently to see if I'm understanding
clarifying, it's a one-off triage of sorts not something we'll have to do regularly
we have some issues identified as P-medium that are maybe ICEs or stuff like that that are ungreat
How many P-medium do we have right now?
my idea is that given that Rust is still young at some point it would reach a maturity level in which such bugs would be P-high
is it something like that what you meant?
only 263
202 T-compiler
anyway, IMHO right now it's not something we should be focusing on
I meant, baby steps :)
ye i agree
let's first close all P-high issues if we ever possibly can :)
my guess is that this will never happen :)
but I'm optimist about it :P
just saying, for example there is an issue like this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/18759 which was opened way back in 2014.
though i agree it is too early to form a process around p-medium/p-low
:+1:
So if we decide to focus on P-high
I truly believe that is very important for this group to focus in the highest priority issues
The issue is that there are too many of them to review each week, right?
if some day the highest priority issues are P-medium, I'd buy you a nice gift @DPC :P
Well I think by definition priorities are relative to each other
yep
So we'll always have high priority issues. Sorry :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
my gift :cry:
anyway I think I do agree with Dylan that today's P-medium issues are maybe tomorrow's P-high as the compiler matures

DPC said:

my gift :cry:

hehe I could even offer a car, because we will never have 0 P-critical and 0 P-high
forget 0 p-critical & 0-high, i'm trying to get issues under 5k and it's a struggle :grinning:
hehe I see you like impossibles :)
anyway, we didn't reach any conclusion about hz issues, I'd ask @pnkfelix for his thoughts about this because he and nikomatsakis I think had some strong thoughts about it
A small thing i would like to add - would be nice if thread names changed when prioritisation is removed

DPC said:

A small thing i would like to add - would be nice if thread names changed when prioritisation is removed

Maybe open an issue about that?
something like [Removed] I-prioritize
So we can discuss async
it's the hour mark. so I think we are done here :slight_smile:

DPC said:

something like [Removed] I-prioritize

maybe P-something issue info
I think we are done, let's wait for Felix to comment on the hz
do we agree on 30 mins meetings?
we generally don't have much to discuss, so agreed
or we spend the last 30 mins doing jokes as today :P

Santiago Pastorino said:

do we agree on 30 mins meetings?

I guess with the clause to re-extend it on the occasion there is a bit more to discuss

apiraino said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

do we agree on 30 mins meetings?

I guess with the clause to re-extend it on the occasion there is a bit more to discuss

right :+1:

apiraino said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

do we agree on 30 mins meetings?

I guess with the clause to re-extend it on the occasion there is a bit more to discuss

only if something's urgent or we can do the usual meeting thing of pushing it to the next steering meeting
we can also schedule specific meetings during this meeting if there's an important topic
anyway, changing the calendar event
and thanks everyone for being here :heart:
:wave: to everyone

Santiago Pastorino said:

I think we are done, let's wait for Felix to comment on the hz

I don't have comments besides "if we find we need to add `Hz-<frequency>, we can do it later." But its not something I see a driving need for right now; it was more something that I thought might be more self-documenting than the current P-priority scheme.
I'd close that issue then for now as not actionable but we should keep an eye on this in the future

Hi! I'm glad there is lots of interest in the perf triage reports. The aim of them much like @pnkfelix suggested: first, to know about improvements and regressions. Second, to try to get action on regressions.

I tweaked the format of this week's report as per @Santiago Pastorino 's request (adding PR numbers to the text). I'm happy to hear other suggestions for changes that would be helpful to other people.
Although the workload isn't onerous, I'm definitely happy to share it. I've done this sort of thing before with crashes in Firefox, and the weekly grind does get wearing after a while.
Plus, I take PTO every so often :)

I don't think it's necessary to do it more than weekly, and for each week's report it doesn't parallelize, as observed above. But having two or three people on the roster and alternating weeks would be fine
@njn yeah, sounds great
A weekly cadence works well. It matches the meeting frequency, and the this-week-in-rust frequency.
the other tweaks that would be nice are:
The README explains the process. I wrote it deliberately so that other people can do it as well.
instead of linking the PRs, linking directly to your comment
I've been updating the README with minor changes as I've improved my process.
so people can directly go there during weekly meetings
and avoid searching for your comment
this is one thing I've heard during the meetings
Sure thing
and the other request I have is if we can have one file per report
so we can possibly automate this in an easier way
What needs to be automated? The links within the file would be equally automatable? Or is this for extracting the info somehow?
sorry, let me explain
here https://hackmd.io/zg0MC_eEQkqvsXO0uQnXpA we have our weekly meeting agenda
that one is the one from last week
as you can see here https://hackmd.io/zg0MC_eEQkqvsXO0uQnXpA#Performance-logs
we are now including your reports and spending some time discussing them during the weekly meetings
we build the agenda in a kind of automated way
if you provide a file per report we can make our agenda building automation easier :)
otherwise we need to download https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/blob/master/triage/2020.md in full and parse extract the corresponding last report

but I guess adding a new file per report may be against what you're trying to do :), so just consider it as a suggestion just in case splitting is exactly the same for you and doesn't break your workflow
Ok, so would a file like rustc-perf/triage/2020-07-14.md work?
Adding a new file every time is a bit annoying, but I can live with it
Especially if I end up only having to do this every two or three weeks :)
Another point about the "once a week is enough" - yesterday there were only 16 commits for the whole week. It's not that many. Maybe it was a bad week in terms of CI and landing PRs.
Hmm, I should probably add a link to the time period for the graphs.

On the "it may be good because we can come up with things that njn may have missed" above... maybe, but probably not. There'd be a ton of duplicated work. Sometimes you get a small change and two people might disagree about whether it's significant, shrug

njn said:

Ok, so would a file like rustc-perf/triage/2020-07-14.md work?

yes

njn said:

Adding a new file every time is a bit annoying, but I can live with it

yeah, if it's very annoying don't worry, really :)

njn said:

On the "it may be good because we can come up with things that njn may have missed" above... maybe, but probably not. There'd be a ton of duplicated work. Sometimes you get a small change and two people might disagree about whether it's significant, shrug

agreed, there are tons of things to do for the project, duplicating work in my opinion is not the best use of resources

Santiago Pastorino said:

if I remember correctly o0Ignition0o - Jeremy Lempereur opened a PR with the priority levels

Sorry I wasn't available yesterday, that is correct. If I recall correctly I need to rephrase a couple of nits, and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-forge/pull/390 will land

o0Ignition0o - Jeremy Lempereur said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

if I remember correctly o0Ignition0o - Jeremy Lempereur opened a PR with the priority levels

Sorry I wasn't available yesterday, that is correct. If I recall correctly I need to rephrase a couple of nits, and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-forge/pull/390 will land

that's great, take your time and let us know when it's ready

A late follow-up here: I currently put the triage logs into files in the rustc-perf repo, but it doesn't have to be that way. E.g. if there's a suitable wiki, that might be more convenient, because the need for a git push or PR is not really helpful for this sort of thing.
@njn what you have done works
another possibility if you want is to place your reports directly in the compiler agenda
but I don't think that's what you want

The compiler agenda would be fine, so long as it is findable and available for me to modify on Tuesday morning Melbourne time. I can link to the appropriate section (e.g. https://hackmd.io/zg0MC_eEQkqvsXO0uQnXpA#Performance-logs) from This Week in Rust.
Overall, that would be easier for everyone. It's nice being able to use a WYSIWYG-type editor and not have to worry about git PRs/commits just for some text.
Where do the compiler agendas live?
I will say that making sure these are preserved in a "log" of some kind that doesn't require scrolling through a bunch of other stuff seems valuable. Is GitHub's editor UI insufficient for this?

njn said:

Where do the compiler agendas live?

We draft them via hackmd.io
See https://hackmd.io/team/rust-compiler-team?nav=overview
I think the pattern has been to start writing up the week's agenda on the Wednesday before the meeting; @Santiago Pastorino posts a link to it when they start writing it.

@njn as @pnkfelix noted if you go to https://hackmd.io/team/rust-compiler-team?nav=overview, you will find at the bottom, under weekly all the agendas of our meetings, you should be looking for the next one and should exist, so this time is 2020-07-16, note that at the bottom you need to paginate but I usually pin the meeting agenda so you should be able to find it in the top of that page too
btw, we would need your HackMD username to give you write access
@Santiago Pastorino Can you give me permission via my GitHub account, nnethercote?

My only concern about using the agenda is that it feels less permanent than files in a GitHub repo. But I guess the useful shelf life of these reports is really only a few weeks or months at most. It's certainly a bit easier.

One other question: for each improvement/regression in the log entry, I link to the explanatory comment in the PR, and also to the perf results. But the explanatory comment also links to the perf results. I wonder if I can omit the results link in the log entry. It would be less work for me, but for anyone to see the perf results they'd have to click through two links. Thoughts?

njn said:

Santiago Pastorino Can you give me permission via my GitHub account, nnethercote?

I've found "you" under the name Nicholas Nethercote, check and confirm that you got an invite

njn said:

My only concern about using the agenda is that it feels less permanent than files in a GitHub repo. But I guess the useful shelf life of these reports is really only a few weeks or months at most. It's certainly a bit easier.

agreed, whatever you prefer would be fine for me

njn said:

One other question: for each improvement/regression in the log entry, I link to the explanatory comment in the PR, and also to the perf results. But the explanatory comment also links to the perf results. I wonder if I can omit the results link in the log entry. It would be less work for me, but for anyone to see the perf results they'd have to click through two links. Thoughts?

I guess the one that can answer this more properly is @pnkfelix
Explanatory comment alone seems fine to me for now, especially if the format of the comment is regular enough that we could plausibly auto scrape the perf link from it if need be
Hey @Santiago Pastorino , I just wanted to double check before today's T-compiler meeting:
My impression is that there seems like enough interest among wg-prioritization itself to try to figure out a way to reduce the "bus factor" of njn 's work on weekly performance evaluations
that I do not need to bring it up amongst the whole T-compiler team at this point
Does that sound correct, @Santiago Pastorino ?
Okay great I'll interpret your :thumbs_up: as affirmation. :slight_smile:
I understood the first sentence, the one I've :+1:

pnkfelix said:

that I do not need to bring it up amongst the whole T-compiler team at this point

didn't get exactly what you meant here
I was considering just now
saying to all of T-compiler
you were thinking to bring that up to other T-compiler members and see if someone is also interested?
"hey, njn might need help with this"
ahh ok ok
but I don't think that we need to do that, at least not yet
:+1:
I was just musing about it while reviewing the agenda for today's meeting
